sentences.sentence: Energy policy The ALP's plan to build non-priority transmission projects will mean higher electricity bills locked in for decades.Chris Bowen's opinion piece on these pages last week served as further proof - if any was needed - of his lack of understanding of the National Electricity Market, and Labor's lack of concern when it comes to keeping electricity bills low for Australian consumers.His claim that the Australian Energy Market Operator's Integrated System Plan is largely unfunded fails even the most basic test.

Thirteen months on from his appointment as the opposition spokesman for climate change and energy, it is clear he still has his training wheels on - as his colleague Joel Fitzgibbon famously put it.The Morrison government has committed more than $500 million to support all major priority transmission projects - valued at more than $12 billion in total - identified in the ISP.

This includes support for Project Energy Connect, Marinus Link, Humelink, QNI Minor and VNI West.Ours is a prudent approach, based on expert advice and a careful consideration of the costs and benefits to consumers.

We are funding those projects identified as part of an optimal development pathway, while monitoring others where the economics don't yet stack up.Labor, in contrast, has shown a wilful disregard for this advice.
It wants to accelerate projects before they stack up for consumers.
The majority of the projects it has earmarked for support are not considered actionable by AEMO.

This means that the cost of construction most likely outweighs the benefits.Labor's approach is exactly what the ISP was designed to prevent - a return to reckless gold-plating and a tax on consumers for decades to come.Labor will offer up $20 billion in taxpayer-funded financing to some of the world's largest pension and sovereign wealth funds from China, the Middle East and Canada to build projects that AEMO has said are not ready to proceed.Only Labor would believe that these funds need additional taxpayer money.Access to finance has never been the issue for bringing well-developed transmission projects to reality.

The real challenge is to get good projects to final investment decision and the lowest cost to consumers, and our support focuses on this.Transmission infrastructure is a regulated asset, meaning its owners have a guaranteed rate of return over the life of the project, which can be up to 50 years.
These costs, in turn, are passed on to consumers.By funding AEMO's non-priority projects, Labor will drive up electricity costs and consumer prices for little economic return.

The legacy of Labor's poorly conceived plan will be higher electricity bills - potentially locked in for decades - and greater hardship and stress for families and businesses.It is the same mistake Labor made when it was last in government.
Back then, overinvestment in the electricity grid saw network charges increase by nearly 70 per cent between 2007 and 2013.

As these charges can be nearly half of an average bill, the impact on our energy-intensive manufacturing sector and household budgets was significant, with the most vulnerable in society suffering the most.The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission has estimated that this past overinvestment still adds an extra $200 to each electricity bill every year.

That's why we have tightened the process to prevent overinvestment in new infrastructure by eliminating the limited merits review process, which was manipulated to increase profits for network providers.Households, businesses and manufacturers cannot withstand another round of gold-plating and waste under Labor.

The Coalition has worked hard to bring electricity prices back down after they more than doubled for households under the Rudd-Gillard-Rudd government.We are continuing to implement a well-considered, balanced plan for electricity that has helped deliver the lowest electricity costs in the National Electricity Market in eight years.This has focused on judicious transmission investment, supporting critical new on-demand dispatchable capacity - so vital for reliability and affordability - and agreement on landmark national reforms in electricity market design.
At the same time, we have overseen record renewable investment, with renewables skyrocketing to nearly 33 per cent of generation in the NEM.Labor's plan is sadly one-dimensional.

It has no plan for large-scale dispatchable generation, its claims of price reductions under its policy have not withstood expert scrutiny, and its one idea for transmission investment casts aside AEMO's plan for the market.A Morrison government will always put outcomes for consumers - families, businesses and our job-creating industries - first.Angus Taylor is the federal Minister for Industry, Energy and Emissions Reduction.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly uncertain about this document. The writing style and content are not particularly AI-like.
